Recommended new audiobooks #6

Written by Sophie Green · Published Feb 21, 2018

CD audiobooks

Sleeping in the Ground by Peter Robinson, read by Mark Meadows

â€œA shocking mass murder occurs at a wedding in a small Dales church and a huge manhunt follows. Eventually, the shooter is run to ground and things take their inevitable course. But Banks is plagued with doubts as to exactly what happened outside the church that day, and why.

â€œStruggling with the death of his first serious girlfriend and the return of profiler Jenny Fuller into his life, Banks feels the need to dig deeper into the murders, and as he does so, he uncovers forensic and psychological puzzles that lead him to the past secrets that might just provide the answers he is looking for. When the surprising truth becomes clear, it is almost too late.â€

Rather be the Devil, by Ian Rankin, read by James Macpherson

â€œJohn Rebus, now a couple of years into his retirement, finds himself drawn into a cold case from the 1970s involving a female socialite, found dead in a bedroom in one of Edinburghâ€™s most luxurious hotels. Itâ€™s a crime over forty years old, but no one was ever found guilty. Now, Rebus has his own reasons to investigate, but it is going to set him against some very dangerous people.â€

Insidious Intent, by Val McDermid, read by Saul Reichlin

â€œWhen charred human remains are discovered in the driverâ€™s seat of a burning car, DCI Carol Jordan and psychological profiler Tony Hill are brought in to investigate. They soon discover that what appeared to be a terrible accident is, in fact, murder. Delving deeper into the case, they begin the dangerous hunt for a most sinister killer with the power to inflict untold fear and pain on their victims.â€

Origin, by Dan Brown, read by Paul Michael

â€œRobert Langdon, Harvard professor of symbology and religious iconology, arrives at the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao to attend the unveiling of a discovery that claims it will change the face of science forever. The eveningâ€™s host is his friend and former student, Edmond Kirsch, a 40-year-old tech magnate whose inventions and audacious predictions have made him a controversial figure. Tonight he claims he will reveal an astonishing scientific breakthrough to challenge the fundamentals of human existence.

â€œBut everyone is left reeling when the meticulously orchestrated evening is blown apart before Kirschâ€™s precious discovery can be revealed. With his life under threat, Langdon is forced into a desperate bid to escape, along with the museumâ€™s director, Ambra Vidal. Together they flee to Barcelona on a perilous quest to locate a cryptic password that will unlock Kirschâ€™s secret.â€

The Keeper of Lost Things, by Ruth Hogan, read by Jane Collingwood

â€œOnce a celebrated author of short stories now in his twilight years, Anthony Peardew has spent half his life lovingly collecting lost objects, trying to atone for a promise broken many years before. Realising he is running out of time, he leaves his house and all its lost treasures to his assistant Laura, the one person he can trust to fulfil his legacy and reunite the thousands of objects with their rightful owners. But the final wishes of the Keeper of Lost Things have unforeseen repercussions which trigger a most serendipitous series of encounters.â€

A Stranger in the House, by Shari LapenÌƒa, read by Tavia Gilbert

â€œYou come home after a long day at work, ready for dinner with your wife. But sheâ€™s not there. And it looks like she left in a blind panic. Her mobile phone and her bag are still in the house. You fear the worst. You call the police. And they tell you that your wifeâ€™s been in an accident. She lost control of her car as she sped through a street on the worst side of town.

â€œBut why would she go there? Was she running towards something? Away from something? The police think she was up to no good. You refuse to believe it. Then you start to wonder. Youâ€™ve been married for three years and you thought you knew her better than anyone on earth. But maybe you donâ€™t.â€

Donâ€™t Wake Up, by Liz Lawler, read by Zara Ramm

â€œAlex Taylor wakes up tied to an operating table. The man who stands over her isnâ€™t a doctor. The choice he forces her to make is utterly unspeakable. But when Alex re-awakens, sheâ€™s unharmed - and no one believes her horrifying story. Ostracised by her colleagues, her family and her partner, she begins to wonder if she really is losing her mind. And then she meets the next victim.â€

Together, by Julie Cohen, read by Gemma Whelan

â€œOn a morning that seems just like any other, Robbie wakes in his bed, his wife Emily asleep beside him, as always. He rises and dresses, makes his coffee, feeds his dogs, just as he usually would. But then he leaves Emily a letter and does something that will break her heart.

â€œAs the years go back all the way to 1962, Robbieâ€™s actions become clearer as we discover the story of a couple with a terrible secret - one they will do absolutely anything to protect.â€

Bloodâ€™s Game, by Angus Donald, read by Damian Lynch

â€œIt is the winter of 1670. Holcroft Blood has entered the employ of the Duke of Buckingham, one of the most powerful men in the kingdom after the king. It is here that his education really begins. With a gift for numbers and decoding ciphers, Holcroft soon proves invaluable to the Duke, but when heâ€™s pushed into a betrayal he risks everything for revenge.

â€œHis father, Colonel Thomas Blood, has fallen on hard times. A man used to fighting, he lives by his wits and survives by whatever means necessary. When heâ€™s asked to commit treason by stealing the crown jewels, he puts himself and his family in a dangerous situation - one that may end at the gallows.

â€œAs the machinations of powerful men plot to secure the countryâ€™s future, both father and son must learn what it is to survive in a more dangerous battlefield than war - the court of King Charles II. One missed step could prove fatal.â€

Dunstan, by Conn Iggulden, read by Geoffrey Beevers

â€œIn the year 937, King Ã†thelstan, grandson of Alfred the Great, readies himself to throw a great spear into the north. His dream of a kingdom of all England will stand or fall on one field and the passage of a single day. At his side is Dunstan of Glastonbury, full of ambition and wit, perhaps enough to damn his soul. After the Fire, by Henning Mankell, read by Sean Barrett

â€œFredrik Welin is a 70-year-old retired doctor. Years ago he retreated to the Swedish archipelago, where he lives alone on an island. He swims in the sea every day, cutting a hole in the ice if necessary. He lives a quiet life. Until he wakes up one night to find his house on fire.

â€œFredrik escapes just in time, wearing two left-footed wellies, as neighbouring islanders arrive to help douse the flames. All that remains in the morning is a stinking ruin and evidence of arson. The house that has been in his family for generations and all his worldly belongings are gone. He cannot think who would do such a thing, or why. Without a suspect, the police begin to think he started the fire himself.â€

â€œFrom the moment its shadow falls over Three Pines, Gamache suspects the creature has deep roots and a dark purpose. When it suddenly vanishes and a body is discovered, it falls to Gamache to discover if a debt has been paid or levied.â€

Secrets in Death, by J. D. Robb, read by Susan Ericksen

â€œNo one is going to miss Larinda Mars. A ruthless gossip queen with a lucrative sideline in blackmail, thereâ€™s no lack of suspects when sheâ€™s murdered in a fashionable New York bar. With so many people wanting her dead, itâ€™s going to be a tough case to crack.

â€œLieutenant Eve Dallas may not like this particular victim, but itâ€™s her duty to bring the killer to justice. Secrets of a Happy Marriage, by Cathy Kelly, read by Caroline Lennon

â€œJojo, Bessâ€™s stepdaughter, has a point to make. Bess is not her mother, and she wonâ€™t replace the one sheâ€™s been missing every day for the last two years. â€œThen Helen tells Nikki that someone is watching her. But is all this in her friendâ€™s imagination and part of her post-traumatic stress?

â€œAnd why is Stephen Cox back in town? Heâ€™s the villain who tore Nikkiâ€™s life apart and he seems to have returned to wreak more chaos. Before long the whole town is on the verge of hysteria and her friendâ€™s fear will lead Nikki and Joseph on a very dangerous trail.â€

Valley of the Shadow, by Carola Dunn, read by Wanda McCaddon

â€œWhile out on a walk, Eleanor Trewynn, her niece Megan, and her neighbor Nick spot a young, half-drowned man floating in the water. â€œThe local police inspector presumes that they are refugees from East Africa, abandoned by the smugglers who brought them into England. â€œâ€˜Look after the deadâ€™, said the priests, â€˜and the dead will look after you.â€™

â€œWise words in all probability, but a tall order when you have just become the pharaoh of a small and penniless country whose largesse - and indeed treasury - is unlikely to stretch to the building of a monumental pyramid to honour your dead father. And particularly when your only visible means of support is a recently acquired qualification from the Guild of Assassins where running a kingdom and basic financial acumen were not prerequisites for course entryâ€¦â€

Can You Keep a Secret?, by Karen Perry, read by Grainne Gillis

â€œItâ€™s been twenty years since Lindsey has seen her best friend Rachel. Twenty years since she has set foot in Thornbury Hall - the now crumbling home of the Bagenal family - where they spent so much time as teenagers. Since Patrick Bagenalâ€™s 18th birthday party, the night everything changed.

â€œPatrick has decided to have one last hurrah before closing the doors of his family home for good. All of the old crowd, back together for a weekend. Ikigai: the Japanese secret to a long and happy life, by HÃ©ctor GarcÃ­a and Francesc Miralles, read by Noako Mori

â€œLearn how Truganiniâ€™s death inspired the Martian invasion of Earth. Discover the role of Hall and Oates in the Myall Creek Massacre. And be reminded why you should never ever smoke with the Wild Colonial Boy and Mad Dan Morgan.â€

Fight Like a Girl, written and read by Clementine Ford

â€œOnline sensation, fearless feminist heroine and scourge of trolls and misogynists everywhere, Clementine Ford is a beacon of hope and inspiration to thousands of women and girls.
